oh, ok.
Hey
So, any good apps already out in the wild?
I'd LOVE to see an iOS friendly web app.
I'd love to see a desktop app
@kennethreitz https://convore.com/convore-api-developers/how-would-a-desktop-app-differ-from-the-in-browser-web-app/

I'm still thinking about some aspects of the interface, It might be interesting to consolidate multiple topics in a single "timeline" so that one can glance at what is going on. What do you guys think?
I'm working on a Mac OS app, might have something to show soon. :)
Cool, go for it ;)
@lmarinho that sounds fantastic
sounds like irc.
@mal You would have to select it, but it would default to the topic of the latest message visible when you started typing.
How would you choose which to post to if there were more than one displayed?
It could be just a url if /api/users/:username:.json returns other information. What do you think?
Most of the API response contains user information with full user information: username, url, id and img.

that sort of thing is always tempting but a) there are plenty of groups with communities in excess of a hundred and even a thousand and b) even when you cache the user info, you still need to periodically check the server to clear stale data. Any way you slice it, that's a lot of requests.
as in messges = (), users = ()
interesting
but have more user info at the user endpoint

and if saving bytes ever became a priority, say when pulling down messages.json, the correct way to do it would be to put the user's ID in the message along with another payload member that included the full user information for all users mentioned elsewhere in the payload - if that makes sense
as such, I'd be miffed if the additional user information was removed from the live endpoint
I think we'll include the user data with the messages for now
in CF it's not a huge deal because the participants lists tend to be much smaller - but it's still a pain
twitters feed is a good example of this
@protocool sort of like yaml does it?
if I get all my followers (e.g.) it brings in a bunch of their details as well, not just ids
I don't think we include much user data anyway

@leah - not sure what you mean by "sort of like yaml does it" - I'm just saying that it's better to reduce repetition in the response payloads than it is to eliminate the information and force additional requests
the campfire transcripts endpoints are a pain to work with because they just contain speaker ids and you have to hit the server again for each non-cached user
okay, we'll leave the repeated info in
yeah - in case I wasn't clear, I like having the repeated info :-)
@leah There's a user endpoint? Gimme!
@protocool Yes, I agree there is always a trade-off. At this moment, it is probably easier just to include it in all the responses.
I thought about it because the user data should be pretty much static.
In terms of the caching, we could use the standard HTTP cache control directives.
Why didn't you use REST for /api/groups/:group_id/leave.json wouldn't DELETE https://convore.com/api/groups/:group_id be better?
I think this would be a better fit for actually deleting the group as it doesn't indicate anything about leaving.

@mrtazz yeah, I thought that after sending that.  Pehaps a /api/groups/memberships.json that can be PUT to or some. Anyway, who cares, I'm just being a RESTful jerk, asking for pure REST for REST sake.
pure rest would have no separate /api/ urls
can't pick and choose
i'm struggling trying to make the api wrapper as intuitive as possible
yeah, that's what i'll do.
maybe groups should be a list w/ dict-like methods
Opinion: api wrapper. groups endpoint dictionary. keys should be group id or group slug?
@kennethreitz I don't know that one either.  id is what's currently used in the other calls, but slug makes sense if you're abstracting out calls too.  group.topics()
currently convore.groups is a dict containing all of the groups you belong to, and if you request an id (or slug) of a group you don't belong to, it'll fetch the info for you
it's so sexy
Can I assume that the timezone is UTC?
nvm, it's epoch seconds
http://dpaste.de/CORx/
Nah, it's cool.  I expected this sort of thing.
@ericflo how long before the feed changes?
my timestamps are right, and I fixed my threading bug.  :)
So I'm doing dt = datetime.datetime.utcnow and saving that to the db, and then time.mktime(dt.timetuple()) + (dt.microsecond / 1000000.0) to generate the stuff back
Boom, that's our problem, it should be calendar.timegm instead of time.mktime.  Sorry about that, fixing it now.
it's fixed now though
hmmmmm
for both date_created and _ts?  I mean, That seems right to me, but without reading through all the datetime docs I'm not positive
@issackelly boom
@ericflo: there is a difference between the _ts value and the date_created value
@ericflo So, I'm trying to sort through what I thought was a bug on my end, but is the timestamp in the live stream UTC and the one in the non-live PST?
They should all be UTC
yup!
no problem.  spent an hour on it this afternoon :P
oh, sorry, you said "fixing it" not "fixed
oh man, I'm so sorry, I simply didn't know :(
@kennethreitz Nope, should be datetime.datetime.utcfromtimestamp
np :)
@ericflo https://github.com/kennethreitz/python-convore/blob/master/convore/api.py#L110-112
should be sufficient?
perfect, thank you
@ericflo is there a situation where login/logout messages might get sent over the live API twice? or is it most likely a bug on my end?
like you're too slow to make a new request and your presence times out
sweet
@kennethreitz don't blame me if you end up needing to change it, it's unofficial :)
@issackelly I haven't seen that bug before (double-login/logout)
could be, but then you'll get a logout, then a login event.  Not a double-logout or double-login
Maybe that's what he meant, is it @issackelly?
true
@ericflo awesome! thanks.
https://convore.com/api/groups/discover/friend.json is 500ing
I'm not exactly sure what the issue is, probably a timing issue on my end
@ericflo is there a way to get a list of *all* groups?

Ok, so I just committed some stuff, and I haven't even run it by @leah or @etmaguire yet, so it's unofficial API at this point, but here are some new API endpoints I just created:
^groups/discover/friend.json
^groups/discover/explore/(?P<angle>popular|recent|alphabetical).json
^groups/discover/category.json
^groups/discover/category/(?P<category>[\w-]+).json
^groups/discover/search.json
already integrating it :)
Search accepts a 'q' query arg
@ericflo the double-login might be due to timing issues
with the live endpoint
unless you meant that to be a friend-id or something
@kennethreitz Yeah, you're hitting it unauthenticated.  I just added a check to make sure the requester is authed
I shouldn't be..
@kennethreitz by the time it's getting to our servers, it doesn't have the basic auth header
Oh, cool, docs don't suggest that.
prob shouldn't be 200 :)
@issackelly Yes, unfortunately it's not a great error message, you also need a group "kind", such as "public" or "private"

@ericflo changed the request to the follow, but got the same error message

name:Public Group Test from Issac, ripe for deletion.
description:
kind:public
Yes, they are out of date, we're sorry :(
w00t http://kreitz.co/3m0J0U1g0q3a2x323M3E

well, 200 code for stuff that doesn't validate is correct, AFAIK

ooh, and just found an intersting quirk of your url parsing

@issackelly Let me see if I can reproduce the group creation issue

Ah yeah, that's because we're using John Gruber's overzealous URL regex, we gotta fix that
Random thought: you might benefit from OrderedDicts

yeah, you beat me to it, but I got the same result.   back to the code

@ericflo I'm not sure, it's not happening now, which worries me, because I didn't change the code.  Before, I submitted that request, and got the same "group name required" even though both name, and kind were set
I just made 3 groups, you can delete them
I'll keep an eye on that one

Since, unlike say, twitter, convore clients don't have an API key, would it be helpful for you to have us set a custom user-agent header or something?  that way, if say, I'm making 100000 request/minute by accident or something you can email me and say "hey dummy! fix your code!"
Python-convore is nearing completion.
On the last endpoint now :)
Although, maybe most apps would just suck it up and grab the group_id.json once and cache that.
Also, in 2011, the live endpoint shouldn't feel like magic.  But it does.  Watching messages appear in my console as I post them in the browser is... stupidly exciting.

Hmm, just playing with the api, primarily the live end point.  I notice that for read, logout and message, I have all the info I think I'd need.  For "topic" it feels like having the group name would often be really helpful.
Cool.
